div1.head: Military Orders for Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed, August 6, 1900
div1.p:
SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 183. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, August 6, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, 2d Lieutenant Ned
M. Green, U. S. Army, recently appointed from corporal,
Company D, 7th U. S. Infantry, with rank from July 30, 1900,
is assigned to the 25th U. S. Infantry, Company C, and upon
the receipt and acceptance by him of his commission will pro-
ceed to join his company at Fort Sam Houston, Texas. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. The following order has been received from the War De-
partment:
WAR DEPARTMENT,Washington, August 6, 1900.

Upon the recommendation of the superintendent of the Military
Academy, Cadet William F. Harrell, 3d class, is by direction of the Presi-
dent dismissed from the service of the United States for harassing and
annoying a 4th class man.

ELIHU ROOT.
Secretary of War.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Acting
Hospital Steward Arthur Eutroppe, Hospital Corps, will upon
arrival at Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, be sent with forty pri-
vates of the Hospital Corps now at that post, and who have
not less than eighteen months to serve, to Fort McDowell,
California, and report upon arrival to the commanding officer
for duty with the Hospital Corps school of instruction at that
post.

4. Private Lewis A. Claflin, Company A, 7th Infantry, now
at Fort Snelling, Minnesota, is transferred to Company M, 8th
Infantry, stationed at that post, and will report to the com-
manding officer thereof for duty.

5. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
James A. O'Reilley. Company F, 4th Infantry, Presidio of
San Francisco, California, is transferred to the general service.
He will be sent to the recruiting station, No. 420 South State
street, Chicago, Illinois, and will report upon arrival to the
officer in charge of that station for duty.

6. Private Michael J. Mahoney, Company B, 3d Infantry,
Manila, Philippine Islands, is transferred to the 3d Cavalry,
stationed at that place. He will be sent to the headquarters

22. By direction of the Secretary of War, so much of para-
graph 19, Special Orders, No. 111, May 11, 1900, from this of-
fice, as directs Captain Joseph E. Kuhn, Corps of Engineers,
U. S. Army, to report in person to the superintendent of the
U. S. Military Academy for duty as instructor in practical
military engineering and the command of Company E, Bat-
talion of Engineers, is so amended as to direct him to report
in person to the superintendent of the U. S. Military Academy
for duty as instructor in practical military engineering and
the command of the engineer detachment on duty at West
Point, New York.

23. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following-
named 2d lieutenants, U. S. Army, recently appointed from
enlisted men, as hereinafter specified, with rank from July 25,
1900, are assigned to the regiments designated opposite their
respective names:
✓

div1.p:
Upon the receipt and acceptance by them of their commis-
sions the officers named will proceed at once to join the regi-
6
ments, troops, or companies to which they are assigned. Those
not assigned to troops or companies in this order will be so
assigned by their respective regimental commanders. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

24. Leave of absence for four months on surgeon's certificate
of disability is granted Captain George S. Hoyle, 1st U. S.
Cavalry.

25. By direction of the Secretary of War, paragraphs 6 and 7,
Special Orders, No. 63, March 16, 1900, relating to Major
Edward T. Comegys, surgeon, U. S. Army, are revoked.

26. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Edward T.
Comegys, surgeon, U. S. Army, now on leave of absence at
Fort Thomas, Kentucky, will proceed without delay to San
Francisco, California, and report in person to the command-
ing general, Department of California, and by telegraph to the
Surgeon General of the Army for further instructions. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

27. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
George B. Taylor, Troop E, 11th Cavalry, U. S. Volunteers,
Army General Hospital, Presidio of San Francisco, California,
will be sent to the Army and Navy General Hospital, Hot
Springs, Arkansas, reporting upon his arrival to the com-
manding officer for treatment in the hospital. The command-
ing officer of the hospital at the Presidio of San Francisco,
California, will forward by mail to the commanding officer of
the hospital at Hot Springs, Arkansas, the descriptive list and
account of pay and clothing of the soldier. Unless this soldier
is a proper subject for discharge for disability or change of
climate, the commanding officer of the hospital will on con-
clusion of treatment send him to his proper station, as required
by Circular, No. 16, of December 8, 1892, from this office.

28. By direction of the Secretary of War, so much of para-
graph 29, Special Orders, No. 174, July 26, 1900, from this
office, as relates to 1st Lieutenant Victor Shepherd, U. S. Vol-
unteer Signal Corps, is so amended as to direct him to proceed
to New York City, New York, and upon arrival report by tele-
graph to the Adjutant General of the Army for further orders.

29. By direction of the Secretary of War, so much of para-
graph 26, Special Orders, No. 178, July 31, 1900, from this office,
as relates to 1st Lieutenant Victor Shepherd, U. S. Volunteer
Signal Corps, is revoked.
